comments.commentBody: Prohibiting bicycles on a national hiking trail is not; that is, NOT outdated and not ill-conceived.  It's smart and terrific policy.  Cyclists should understand that they do a lot of damage to trail infrastructure.  Hiking and cycling are incompatible on the same trails because cyclists have little to no regard for hiking and hikers.  I can readily envision dreadful accidents occurring at the fault of cyclists.  Every, and I mean every, hiker and walker has an unpleasant cyclist interaction story, two or three to tell.  The only people who do not understand this are the selfish cyclists.

David- I'm sorry that you might feel like you might need to stab a cyclist with your ice pick. That's unfortunate. Despite riding big scary bicycles, the majority of us aren't aggressive (I mean we're a bunch of dorks riding bikes in the woods- it's not like we're doing something cool like playing football, shooting stuff, or beating back unruly hoards with ice picks).

If there's a rider out there that's a jerk, they're certainly also a jerk off their bike. Choosing to ride a bike doesn't make a person rude, and being rude doesn't make a person choose to get on a bike. People are what they are. Bummer that you've run into some bad ones.

It sounds like no one here is familiar with backcountry riding. Loaded with camping gear, I'm lucky if I can average 5mph on a trail. I'm not ripping, shredding, or scorching the earth (it sounds like some of you might have mountain biking confused with strip mining and mountain top removal). I stop and talk if I see a hiker- after all, we have a lot in common.

I like being in the backcountry, I like riding my bike. Other people like to walk. My way isn't better, it's just what makes me happy. I wish that some very vocal hikers could be ok with that, instead of trying to legislate a perfectly legitimate way of travel out of existence.

And I'd love to see some citations for the damage that tires cause compared to boots and hooves. If you did some research, you might find that your claims are unfounded.

Cyclist--I disagree. It is not an outdated policy. My wife and I have hiked hundreds of miles in the past few years, so have seen this issue up close.

Of course many cyclists are considerate. We, in fact, are also cyclists--road cyclists averaging about 2000 miles/year.

However, cyclists and hikers do not mix well on trails. Although a minority, some cyclist do barrel down the trails so fast that as a hiker you have to be constantly "on guard," which obliterates the hiking experience. Although cyclists are supposed to give the right of way to hikers, in practical terms this isn't true. Each time a cyclist and a hiker meet it is the hiker who has to step off of the trail.

Having said that, we are in favor of bikers and hikers working together to solve some of these issues. We all have common interests that make it to our mutual benefit to work these issues out so we can all find ways of enjoying the outdoors together. But my point is that it is more of a problem for hikers than you seem to be making it out to be. One step in our "coming together" is for cyclists to really get it that their presence on the trails changes the nature of the experience for hikers in significant ways.

I do wish that, in one of his annual paeans to the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail, Mr. Kristof would address the outdated government policy against bicyclists on the trail.

In 1987, people nervous about bicycles pressed the U.S. Forest Service to enact a no-bikes regulation for the PCT. Forest Service headquarters in Washington apparently took no interest. So, in 1988, three local Forest Service managers were talked into issuing their own closure directive. In a likely violation of federal law, no public notice or opportunity for comment was issued.

The directive has lingered ever since, through a combination of government inertia and people who think 100% access for them and 0% for mountain bikers is fine, as opposed to allowing bicycle access on certain days or times of the year.

It would be interesting to see what a court challenge to the directive would produce. My guess is that it would be invalidated. But why not just rescind it, when we know so much about managing bicycles on trails, something that was a mystery in 1988?

The bicycle ban is a foolish policy. Half or more of the PCT is not well-maintained; parts of it are disappearing and the land is returning to its natural state. Mountain bikers would provide a lot of maintenance help.

For more information, see the website of the Pacific Crest Trail Reassessment Initiative, www.SharingThePCT.org.

Horse racing is by no means the monumental mosh pit of brutality you are depicting here.  Of course there are a few cheaters and not-so-nice people involved, just like any area of life.  Horses love to run - they run in the rain, they run in good weather, they just run.  They run better when they are treated well, and I don't think any horse can be forced to run his best against his will.  I have owned horses for 50 years, and in my youth worked in a racing stable for about a year (part-time).  The horses were treated fantastically well.   And yes, there are injuries, just like in any sport.  There are also injuries -- serious, life-threatening injuries - to horses in the pasture.  Horse racing is a terrific sport that honors mankind's long relationship and history with horses, and is thrilling to watch.

Linda: Many slaveowners in the 1800s treated their slaves like family. Most did not. Some were "bad apples" who tortured their slaves. It is the institution of slavery that we reject, regardless any particular slaveowner's treatment of slaves.

It is the same with nonhuman animal ownership and exploitation. It is the institution that inevitably leads to widespread, routine, and severe abuse and cruelty. The institution of animal exploitation in 2015 is as wrong as the institution of human slavery was in 1850. We have excellent non-animal alternatives in food, clothing, entertainment, and research in 2015. It's time to move on from old, cruel institutions.

And once again: NYT, please stop romanticizing horse racing. These horses aren't Olympians participating in a race of their own volition, but rather owned commodities who are often brutalized, drugged and grotesquely injured. Then turned into dog food or horse meat once they fail to win races. You are a journalistic newspaper not a propaganda machine for the horse racing industry. Do you, editors, writers, individuals involved in making this story--given that the brutality of horse-racing is well documented--have no conscience?

I agree 100%, br.  A lot of ignorance shows up when thoroughbred racing is the topic. It is not known as"The Sport of Kings" for nothing. I worked 8 years at a well known track in Louisiana in the 1980's, and have been betting them for over 40 years. I love Belmont Park. The only European style track in the US. I've been to almost every Belmont Stakes since I moved here 27 years ago.  I watched Secretariat, Seattle Slew & Affirmed (who had Alydar) win the last Triple Crown. My favorite Belmont Stakes since then was 1989, when it was Sunday Silence & Easy Goer. I read Woody Stephens told his friend Charlie Whittingham "those buildings get mighty tall when you cross the Hudson". I saw Andy Beyer that Belmont Stakes Day, & I told him I was a huge fan of his, etc. He was the kindest guy; he spoke to me for maybe 10 minutes. He agreed with my pick: Easy Goer, by a lot. He won by 8, (& ran the 2nd fastest Belmont to Big Red). However, he lost by a rapidly diminishing head to Sunday Silence in The Breeder's Cup (after ducking into the rail at the start; CD fixed the portable rail later) & Horse of The Year.  Later that year, on Jockey Club Gold Cup Day (it was still a mile & a half) it was a gorgeous fall day at Belmont, with their (then) most valuable Stakes @ $1,000,000. Only 18,000 people showed up to see Easy Goer crush the field against his elders (after doing so in The Whitney & The Woodward). That is the day I truly realized most betting being done off track. I was very sad.

Horse racing is a dying sport because it breeds no loyalty. The biggest races of the year are run by 3-year-olds, 2 weeks apart, and when a great horse like Secretariat or Seattle Slew arises they are retired to stud and never race again.

Imagine how many people would watch Golf if Tiger Woods had won the British Open, the Masters, and they US Open over the course of a month his second season as a pro, then retired.

If you want to raise interest in horse racing, make the Kentucky Derby for 3 year olds, the Preakness for 4 year olds, and the Belmont Stakes for 5 year olds. Or open them to horses of any age, so the champion from one year can race the champion from the next.
